under Art. 136 and were granted special leave. At first blush, 0. XXXVII, r. 2 2 , appears drastically to curtail a litigants normal rights
0. XXXVII, r. 2 2 , appears drastically to curtail a litigants normal rights in a Court of justice, namely to appear and defend himself as of right,

concepts.interpretation: Drastically curtails defendant's normal right to appear and defend unless leave obtained; rigour softened by r.3(1).

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: r defend the suit unless he obtains leave from a judge as hereinafter provided so to appear and defend. But the rigour of that is softened by r. 3 1

concepts.unlisted_description: Requires defendant to obtain leave to defend summary suit on bill of exchange etc.

anchor.surface_text: Clause  1  runs- The Court shall, upon application by the defendant, give leave to appear and to defend the suit, upon affidavits which disclose such facts as would make it incumbent on the holder to prove consideration, or such other facts as the Court may deem sufficient to support the application.

concepts.interpretation: Court obligatory to grant leave if affidavit discloses facts requiring proof of consideration or other sufficient facts.

anchor.surface_text: Now what we are examining here are laws of procedure. The spirit in which questions about procedure are to be approached and the manner in which rules relating to them are to be interpreted are laid down in Sangrayn Singh v. Election Tribunal, Kotah, Bhurey Lal Baya . Now a code of procedure must be regarded as such. It is procedure, something designed to facilitate justice and further its ends number a penal enactment for punishment and penalties number a, thing designed to trip people up.

anchor.surface_text: But if the discretion is exercised arbitrarily, or is based on a mis- understanding of the principles that govern its exercise, then interference is called for if there has been a resultant failure of justice

holdings.text: If the facts alleged by the defendant in the affidavit are duly proved, they afford a good or plausible answer to the plaintiff's claim, then leave to defend must be given unconditionally.
holdings.reasoning_summary: At leave stage, court assesses only if pleaded facts if proved would succeed; proof follows after unconditional leave; citing precedents like Jacobs v. Booths.

holdings.text: Court's discretion under Order XXXVII r.3(2) must be exercised judicially in consonance with principles of natural justice.

anchor.surface_text: Applied to the present case, these observations mean that though the Court is given a discretion it must be exercised along judicial lines, and that in turn means, in consonance with the principles of natural justice that form the foundations of our laws.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural laws grounded in natural justice (audi alteram partem); discretion not unfettered but along judicial lines; from Sangram Singh precedent.

holdings.text: Leave to defend may be given subject to conditions if defence not bona fide or to ensure speedy trial by preventing prolongation.

anchor.surface_text: All that we need say about them is that if the Court is of opinion that the defence is not bona fide, then it can impose conditions and is not tied down to refusing leave to defend.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agrees with precedents (Gopala Rao etc.); conditions for sham defences or delay tactics, but conclusion of non-bona fides must be judicial.

holdings.text: Interference warranted if discretion exercised arbitrarily or based on misunderstanding of principles causing failure of justice.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Modifies general non-interference rule; applies where lower courts misapplied triable issue test requiring premature proof.

holdings.text: Defendants' defence raises triable issue as pleaded facts (cheque as collateral security, payments made) if proved afford plausible answer.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Specific application: precise dates, cheque numbers pleaded; trial judge agreed triable but erred on bona fides; no documents needed at affidavit stage.

holdings.text: No requirement to produce documents at affidavit stage for leave to defend; defence not vague merely for lack of evidence before leave granted.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Stage of proof after leave; imposing conditions for lack of docs misunderstands procedure; leads to illusory leave.

holdings.text: Procedural laws must be interpreted to facilitate justice with elasticity, not technically to frustrate it.

anchor.surface_text: Now a code of procedure must be regarded as such. It is procedure, something designed to facilitate justice and further its ends not a penal enactment for punishment and penalties not a, thing designed to trip people up.

holdings.reasoning_summary: From Sangram Singh; general principle applied to O XXXVII interpretation.

holdings.text: Principles of natural justice require no condemnation unheard; applies to procedure under Order XXXVII.

anchor.surface_text: Next, there must be ever present to the mind the fact that our laws of procedure are grounded on a principle of natural justice which requires that men should number be companydemned unheard, that decisions should number be reached behind their backs,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Foundational for discretion exercise; exceptions clearly defined.

holdings.text: Appeal allowed; orders of High Court and trial court set aside; case remanded for trial of issues.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is allowed. We set aside the orders of the High Court and the learned trial Judge and remand the case to the first Court for trial of the issues raised by the defendants.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Resultant from errors below causing miscarriage of justice.
